conclusion: To determine whether the distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is greater than 100 meters or less than 100 meters, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph provided.
At t = 0 s, the velocity is 0 m/s.
At t = 10 s, the velocity is 20 m/s.
At t = 15 s, the velocity is 10 m/s.
The velocity is 20 m/s during the 0 to 10 s interval.
The distance fallen during the 0 to 10 s interval can be calculated using the formula: distance = velocity × time.
Distance fallen during the 0 to 10 s interval is 20 m/s × 10 s = 200 m.
The velocity is 10 m/s during the 10 to 15 s interval.
The distance fallen during the 10 to 15 s interval can be calculated using the formula: distance = velocity × time.
Distance fallen during the 10 to 15 s interval is 10 m/s × 5 s = 50 m.
The distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is 200 m.
The distance fallen during the 10 to 15 seconds interval is 50 m.
The distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is greater than 100 meters.
The final answer is yes, the distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is greater than 100 meters.
